					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Google</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 168 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-168" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">168 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

					<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
					
					
					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">American multinational technology company</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the company. For the search engine provided by the company, see <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google Search</a>. For the parent company with the stock tickers GOOG and GOOGL, see <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet Inc.</a> For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Google_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Google (disambiguation)">Google (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p><p class="mw-empty-elt">

</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="padding-right: 0.5em;">Website</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height: 1.35em;"><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://about.google/">about<wbr />.google</a></span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-below" style="line-height: 1.35em;"><b>Footnotes&#160;/&#32;references</b><br /><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:0_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-9">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Eric Schmidt, Sergey Brin, and Larry Page sitting together" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg/220px-Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg/330px-Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg/440px-Schmidt-Brin-Page-20080520.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2916" data-file-height="2217" /></a><figcaption>Then Chairman and CEO <a href="/wiki/Eric_Schmidt" title="Eric Schmidt">Eric Schmidt</a> (left) with co-founders <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Brin" title="Sergey Brin">Sergey Brin</a> (center) and <a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a> (right) in 2008</figcaption></figure>
<p><b>Google LLC</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɡ/: &#39;g&#39; in &#39;guy&#39;">ɡ</span><span title="/uː/: &#39;oo&#39; in &#39;goose&#39;">uː</span><span title="/ɡ/: &#39;g&#39; in &#39;guy&#39;">ɡ</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="&#39;l&#39; in &#39;lie&#39;">l</span></span>/</a></span>&#32;<span class="ext-phonos skin-invert"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-1" class="ext-phonos-PhonosButton noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" data-ooui="{&quot;_&quot;:&quot;mw.Phonos.PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/transcoded\/3\/3d\/En-us-googol.ogg\/En-us-googol.ogg.mp3&quot;,&quot;rel&quot;:[&quot;nofollow&quot;],&quot;framed&quot;:false,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;volumeUp&quot;,&quot;data&quot;:{&quot;ipa&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;lang&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,&quot;wikibase&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;file&quot;:&quot;En-us-googol.ogg&quot;},&quot;classes&quot;:[&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;noexcerpt&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel&quot;]}"><a role="button" tabindex="0" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/3d/En-us-googol.ogg/En-us-googol.ogg.mp3" rel="nofollow" aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-googol.ogg" title="File:En-us-googol.ogg">ⓘ</a></sup></span></span>, <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">GOO</span>-ghəl</i></a>) is an American <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Technology_company" title="Technology company">technology company</a> focusing on <a href="/wiki/Online_advertising" title="Online advertising">online advertising</a>, <a href="/wiki/Search_engine" title="Search engine">search engine</a> technology, <a href="/wiki/Cloud_computing" title="Cloud computing">cloud computing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Software" title="Software">computer software</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quantum_computing" title="Quantum computing">quantum computing</a>, <a href="/wiki/E-commerce" title="E-commerce">e-commerce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">artificial intelligence</a> (AI).<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> It has been referred to as "the most powerful company in the world"<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> and is one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_valuable_brands" title="List of most valuable brands">most valuable brands</a> due to its <a href="/wiki/Dominance_(economics)" title="Dominance (economics)">market dominance</a>, data collection, and technological advantages in the field of AI.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Google's parent company, <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet Inc.</a> is one of the five <a href="/wiki/Big_Tech" title="Big Tech">Big Tech</a> companies, alongside <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meta_Platforms" title="Meta Platforms">Meta</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>.
</p><p>Google was founded on September 4, 1998, by <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">American</a> computer scientists <a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Brin" title="Sergey Brin">Sergey Brin</a> while they were <a href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy" title="Doctor of Philosophy">PhD</a> students at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>. Together, they own about 14% of its publicly listed shares and control 56% of its stockholder voting power through <a href="/wiki/Super-voting_stock" title="Super-voting stock">super-voting stock</a>. The company went <a href="/wiki/Public_company" title="Public company">public</a> via an <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">initial public offering</a> (IPO) in 2004. In 2015, Google was reorganized as a wholly owned <a href="/wiki/Subsidiary" title="Subsidiary">subsidiary</a> of Alphabet Inc. Google is Alphabet's largest subsidiary and is a <a href="/wiki/Holding_company" title="Holding company">holding company</a> for Alphabet's internet properties and interests. <a href="/wiki/Sundar_Pichai" title="Sundar Pichai">Sundar Pichai</a> was appointed CEO of Google on October 24, 2015, replacing <a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a>, who became the CEO of <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet</a>. On December 3, 2019, Pichai also became the CEO of Alphabet.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The company has since rapidly grown to offer <a href="/wiki/List_of_Google_products" title="List of Google products">a multitude of products and services</a> beyond <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google Search</a>, many of which hold dominant market positions. These products address a wide range of use cases, including <a href="/wiki/Email" title="Email">email</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gmail" title="Gmail">Gmail</a>), navigation (<a href="/wiki/Waze" title="Waze">Waze</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Google_Maps" title="Google Maps">Maps</a>), <a href="/wiki/Cloud_computing" title="Cloud computing">cloud computing</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Cloud_Platform" title="Google Cloud Platform">Cloud</a>), <a href="/wiki/Web_navigation" title="Web navigation">web navigation</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Chrome" title="Google Chrome">Chrome</a>), <a href="/wiki/Online_video_platform" title="Online video platform">video sharing</a> (<a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>), productivity (<a href="/wiki/Google_Workspace" title="Google Workspace">Workspace</a>), <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">operating systems</a> (<a href="/wiki/Android_(operating_system)" title="Android (operating system)">Android</a>), <a href="/wiki/Cloud_storage" title="Cloud storage">cloud storage</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Drive" title="Google Drive">Drive</a>), <a href="/wiki/Translation" title="Translation">language translation</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Translate" title="Google Translate">Translate</a>), photo storage (<a href="/wiki/Google_Photos" title="Google Photos">Photos</a>), <a href="/wiki/Videotelephony" title="Videotelephony">videotelephony</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Meet" title="Google Meet">Meet</a>), <a href="/wiki/Home_automation" title="Home automation">smart home</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Nest" title="Google Nest">Nest</a>), <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphones</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Pixel" title="Google Pixel">Pixel</a>), <a href="/wiki/Wearable_technology" title="Wearable technology">wearable technology</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pixel_Watch" title="Pixel Watch">Pixel Watch</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Fitbit" title="Fitbit">Fitbit</a>), <a href="/wiki/Music_streaming_service" title="Music streaming service">music streaming</a> (<a href="/wiki/YouTube_Music" title="YouTube Music">YouTube Music</a>), video on demand (<a href="/wiki/YouTube_TV" title="YouTube TV">YouTube TV</a>), <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">AI</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Assistant" title="Google Assistant">Google Assistant</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Gemini_(chatbot)" title="Gemini (chatbot)">Gemini</a>), machine learning APIs (<a href="/wiki/TensorFlow" title="TensorFlow">TensorFlow</a>), AI chips (<a href="/wiki/Tensor_Processing_Unit" title="Tensor Processing Unit">TPU</a>), and more. <a href="/wiki/List_of_Google_products#Discontinued_products_and_services" title="List of Google products">Discontinued Google products</a> include <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">gaming</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_Stadia" title="Google Stadia">Stadia</a>), <a href="/wiki/Google_Glass" title="Google Glass">Glass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google%2B" title="Google+">Google+</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Reader" title="Google Reader">Reader</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Play_Music" title="Google Play Music">Play Music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Nexus" title="Google Nexus">Nexus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Hangouts" title="Google Hangouts">Hangouts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Inbox_by_Gmail" title="Inbox by Gmail">Inbox by Gmail</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google's other ventures outside of <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">internet services</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a> include <a href="/wiki/Quantum_computing" title="Quantum computing">quantum computing</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sycamore_processor" title="Sycamore processor">Sycamore</a>), <a href="/wiki/Self-driving_car" title="Self-driving car">self-driving cars</a> (<a href="/wiki/Waymo" title="Waymo">Waymo</a>, formerly the <a href="/wiki/Waymo#History" title="Waymo">Google Self-Driving Car Project</a>), smart cities (<a href="/wiki/Sidewalk_Labs" title="Sidewalk Labs">Sidewalk Labs</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Transformer_(deep_learning_architecture)" title="Transformer (deep learning architecture)">transformer models</a> (<a href="/wiki/Google_DeepMind" title="Google DeepMind">Google DeepMind</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google and <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> are the two <a href="/wiki/List_of_most-visited_websites" title="List of most-visited websites">most-visited websites</a> worldwide followed by <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a> and <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">X</a> (formerly known as <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>). Google is also the largest <a href="/wiki/Search_engine" title="Search engine">search engine</a>, mapping and <a href="/wiki/Navigation" title="Navigation">navigation</a> <a href="/wiki/Application_software" title="Application software">application</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mailbox_provider" title="Mailbox provider">email provider</a>, <a href="/wiki/Productivity_software#Office_suite" title="Productivity software">office suite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Online_video_platform" title="Online video platform">online video platform</a>, <a href="/wiki/Photograph" title="Photograph">photo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cloud_storage" title="Cloud storage">cloud storage</a> provider, <a href="/wiki/Mobile_operating_system" title="Mobile operating system">mobile operating system</a>, <a href="/wiki/Web_browser" title="Web browser">web browser</a>, machine learning framework, and <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">AI</a> <a href="/wiki/Virtual_assistant" title="Virtual assistant">virtual assistant</a> provider in the world as measured by market share.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> On the list of most valuable brands, Google is ranked second by <a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> and fourth by Interbrand.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> It has <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Google" title="Criticism of Google">received significant criticism</a> involving issues such as <a href="/wiki/Privacy_concerns_with_Google" title="Privacy concerns with Google">privacy concerns</a>, <a href="#Tax_avoidance_strategies">tax avoidance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_by_Google" title="Censorship by Google">censorship</a>, <a href="/wiki/Search_neutrality" title="Search neutrality">search neutrality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Competition_law#United_States_antitrust" title="Competition law">antitrust</a> and abuse of its <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a> position.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Google" title="History of Google">History of Google</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Alphabet" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Alphabet">List of mergers and acquisitions by Alphabet</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet Inc.</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google_page_brin.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Google_page_brin.jpg/220px-Google_page_brin.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Google_page_brin.jpg/330px-Google_page_brin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Google_page_brin.jpg/440px-Google_page_brin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1541" data-file-height="1073" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Brin" title="Sergey Brin">Sergey Brin</a> in 2003</figcaption></figure>
<p>Google began in January 1996 as a research project by <a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Brin" title="Sergey Brin">Sergey Brin</a> while they were both PhD students at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-howwestarted_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howwestarted-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Coronabook_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coronabook-23">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-milestones_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milestones-24">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> The project initially involved an unofficial "third founder", <a href="/wiki/Scott_Hassan" title="Scott Hassan">Scott Hassan</a>, the original lead programmer who wrote much of the code for the original <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google Search</a> engine, but he left before Google was officially founded as a company;<sup id="cite_ref-vanityfair_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vanityfair-25">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> Hassan went on to pursue a career in <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">robotics</a> and founded the company <a href="/wiki/Willow_Garage" title="Willow Garage">Willow Garage</a> in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>While conventional search engines ranked results by counting how many times the search terms appeared on the page, they theorized about a better system that analyzed the relationships among websites.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> They called this algorithm <a href="/wiki/PageRank" title="PageRank">PageRank</a>; it determined a website's <a href="/wiki/Relevance_(information_retrieval)" title="Relevance (information retrieval)">relevance</a> by the number of pages, and the importance of those pages that linked back to the original site.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> Page told his ideas to Hassan, who began writing the code to implement Page's ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-vanityfair_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vanityfair-25">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Page and Brin originally nicknamed the new search engine "<a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">BackRub</a>", because the system checked backlinks to estimate the importance of a site.<sup id="cite_ref-howwestarted_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howwestarted-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> Hassan as well as Alan Steremberg were cited by Page and Brin as being critical to the development of Google. <a href="/wiki/Rajeev_Motwani" title="Rajeev Motwani">Rajeev Motwani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Terry_Winograd" title="Terry Winograd">Terry Winograd</a> later co-authored with Page and Brin the first paper about the project, describing PageRank and the initial prototype of the Google search engine, published in 1998. <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Garc%C3%ADa-Molina" title="Héctor García-Molina">Héctor García-Molina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jeffrey_Ullman" title="Jeffrey Ullman">Jeffrey Ullman</a> were also cited as contributors to the project.<sup id="cite_ref-originalpaper_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-originalpaper-34">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> PageRank was influenced by a similar page-ranking and site-scoring algorithm earlier used for <a href="/wiki/Baidu#History" title="Baidu">RankDex</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Robin_Li" title="Robin Li">Robin Li</a> in 1996, with Larry Page's PageRank patent including a citation to Li's earlier RankDex patent; Li later went on to create the Chinese search engine <a href="/wiki/Baidu" title="Baidu">Baidu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Eventually, they changed the name to <i>Google</i>; the name of the search engine was a misspelling of the word <i><a href="/wiki/Googol" title="Googol">googol</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-howwestarted_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howwestarted-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> a very <a href="/wiki/Large_number" class="mw-redirect" title="Large number">large number</a> written <b>10<sup>100</sup></b> (1 followed by 100 zeros), picked to signify that the search engine was intended to provide large quantities of information.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google1998.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Google&#39;s homepage in 1998" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b7/Google1998.png/250px-Google1998.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="139" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b7/Google1998.png/375px-Google1998.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/b/b7/Google1998.png 2x" data-file-width="423" data-file-height="235" /></a><figcaption>Google's original homepage had a simple design because the company founders had little experience in <a href="/wiki/HTML" title="HTML">HTML</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Markup_language" title="Markup language">markup language</a> used for designing web pages<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Google was initially funded by an August 1998 investment of $100,000 from <a href="/wiki/Andy_Bechtolsheim" title="Andy Bechtolsheim">Andy Bechtolsheim</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-howwestarted_22-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howwestarted-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> co-founder of <a href="/wiki/Sun_Microsystems" title="Sun Microsystems">Sun Microsystems</a>. This initial investment served as a motivation to incorporate the company to be able to use the funds.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bechtolsheim_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bechtolsheim-42">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> Page and Brin initially approached <a href="/wiki/David_Cheriton" title="David Cheriton">David Cheriton</a> for advice because he had a nearby office in Stanford, and they knew he had startup experience, having recently sold the company he co-founded, Granite Systems, to <a href="/wiki/Cisco" title="Cisco">Cisco</a> for $220 million. David arranged a meeting with Page and Brin and his Granite co-founder Andy Bechtolsheim. The meeting was set for 8 a.m. at the front porch of David's home in Palo Alto and it had to be brief because Andy had another meeting at Cisco, where he now worked after the acquisition, at 9 a.m. Andy briefly tested a demo of the website, liked what he saw, and then went back to his car to grab the check. David Cheriton later also joined in with a $250,000 investment.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google received money from two other <a href="/wiki/Angel_investor" title="Angel investor">angel investors</a> in 1998: <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon.com</a> founder <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Bezos" title="Jeff Bezos">Jeff Bezos</a>, and entrepreneur <a href="/wiki/Ram_Shriram" title="Ram Shriram">Ram Shriram</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-endofworld_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-endofworld-45">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> Page and Brin had first approached Shriram, who was a venture capitalist, for funding and counsel, and Shriram invested $250,000 in Google in February 1998. Shriram knew Bezos because Amazon had acquired Junglee, at which Shriram was the president. It was Shriram who told Bezos about Google. Bezos asked Shriram to meet Google's founders and they met six months after Shriram had made his investment when Bezos and his wife were on a vacation trip to the Bay Area. Google's initial funding round had already formally closed but Bezos' status as CEO of Amazon was enough to persuade Page and Brin to extend the round and accept his investment.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Between these initial investors, friends, and family Google raised around $1,000,000, which is what allowed them to open up their original shop in <a href="/wiki/Menlo_Park,_California" title="Menlo Park, California">Menlo Park, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Google_Inc_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Google_Inc-48">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Craig_Silverstein" title="Craig Silverstein">Craig Silverstein</a>, a fellow PhD student at Stanford, was hired as the first employee.<sup id="cite_ref-milestones_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milestones-24">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After some additional, small investments through the end of 1998 to early 1999,<sup id="cite_ref-endofworld_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-endofworld-45">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> a new $25 million round of funding was announced on June 7, 1999,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> with major investors including the <a href="/wiki/Venture_capital" title="Venture capital">venture capital</a> firms <a href="/wiki/Kleiner_Perkins" title="Kleiner Perkins">Kleiner Perkins</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sequoia_Capital" title="Sequoia Capital">Sequoia Capital</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bechtolsheim_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bechtolsheim-42">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> Both firms were initially reticent about investing jointly in Google, as each wanted to retain a larger percentage of control over the company to themselves. Larry and Sergey however insisted in taking investments from both. Both venture companies finally agreed to investing jointly $12.5 million each due to their belief in Google's great potential and through the mediation of earlier angel investors Ron Conway and Ram Shriram who had contacts in the venture companies.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Growth">Growth</span></h3>
<p>In March 1999, the company moved its offices to <a href="/wiki/Palo_Alto,_California" title="Palo Alto, California">Palo Alto, California</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> which is home to several prominent <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a> technology start-ups.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> The next year, Google began selling advertisements associated with search keywords against Page and Brin's initial opposition toward an advertising-funded search engine.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-milestones_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milestones-24">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> To maintain an uncluttered page design, advertisements were solely text-based.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> In June 2000, it was announced that Google would become the default search engine provider for <a href="/wiki/Yahoo!" title="Yahoo!">Yahoo!</a>, one of the most popular websites at the time, replacing <a href="/wiki/Inktomi" title="Inktomi">Inktomi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Google&#39;s first servers, showing lots of exposed wiring and circuit boards" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg/170px-Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="281" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg/255px-Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg/340px-Google%E2%80%99s_First_Production_Server.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2543" data-file-height="4209" /></a><figcaption>Google's first production server<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>In 2003, after outgrowing two other locations, the company leased an office complex from <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Graphics" title="Silicon Graphics">Silicon Graphics</a>, at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway in <a href="/wiki/Mountain_View,_California" title="Mountain View, California">Mountain View, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sgibldg_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sgibldg-60">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> The complex became known as the <a href="/wiki/Googleplex" title="Googleplex">Googleplex</a>, a play on the word <a href="/wiki/Googolplex" title="Googolplex">googolplex</a>, the number one followed by a googol of zeroes. Three years later, Google bought the property from SGI for $319&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-googleplexpurchase_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-googleplexpurchase-61">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> By that time, the name "Google" had found its way into everyday language, causing the verb "<a href="/wiki/Google_(verb)" title="Google (verb)">google</a>" to be added to the <i><a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster_Collegiate_Dictionary" class="mw-redirect" title="Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary">Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i>, denoted as: "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet".<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> The first use of the verb on television appeared in an October 2002 episode of <i><a href="/wiki/Buffy_the_Vampire_Slayer" title="Buffy the Vampire Slayer">Buffy the Vampire Slayer</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Additionally, in 2001 Google's investors felt the need to have a strong internal management, and they agreed to hire <a href="/wiki/Eric_Schmidt" title="Eric Schmidt">Eric Schmidt</a> as the chairman and CEO of Google.<sup id="cite_ref-Google_Inc_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Google_Inc-48">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> Eric was proposed by <a href="/wiki/John_Doerr" title="John Doerr">John Doerr</a> from Kleiner Perkins. He had been trying to find a CEO that Sergey and Larry would accept for several months, but they rejected several candidates because they wanted to retain control over the company. <a href="/wiki/Michael_Moritz" title="Michael Moritz">Michael Moritz</a> from Sequoia Capital at one point even menaced requesting Google to immediately pay back Sequoia's $12.5m investment if they did not fulfill their promise to hire a chief executive officer, which had been made verbally during investment negotiations. Eric was not initially enthusiastic about joining Google either, as the company's full potential had not yet been widely recognized at the time, and as he was occupied with his responsibilities at <a href="/wiki/Novell" title="Novell">Novell</a> where he was CEO. As part of him joining, Eric agreed to buy $1 million of Google preferred stocks as a way to show his commitment and to provide funds Google needed.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Initial_public_offering">Initial public offering</span></h3>
<p>On August 19, 2004, Google became a <a href="/wiki/Public_company" title="Public company">public company</a> via an <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">initial public offering</a>. At that time Page, Brin and Schmidt agreed to work together at Google for 20 years, until the year 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> The company offered 19,605,052 shares at a price of $85 per share.<sup id="cite_ref-IPO_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPO-67">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-68">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> Shares were sold in an online auction format using a system built by <a href="/wiki/Morgan_Stanley" title="Morgan Stanley">Morgan Stanley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">Credit Suisse</a>, underwriters for the deal.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> The sale of $1.67 billion gave Google a <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of more than $23 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-washpost_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-washpost-71">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg/170px-Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg/255px-Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg/340px-Eric_Schmidt_at_the_37th_G8_Summit_in_Deauville_037.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2645" data-file-height="3541" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Eric_Schmidt" title="Eric Schmidt">Eric Schmidt</a>, CEO of Google from 2001 to 2011</figcaption></figure>
<p>On November 13, 2006, Google acquired <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> for $1.65 billion in Google stock,<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> On July 20, 2007, Google bids $4.6 billion for the wireless-spectrum auction by the FCC.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> On March 11, 2008, Google acquired <a href="/wiki/DoubleClick" title="DoubleClick">DoubleClick</a> for $3.1&#160;billion, transferring to Google valuable relationships that DoubleClick had with Web publishers and advertising agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> By 2011, Google was handling approximately 3 billion searches per day. To handle this workload, Google built 11 <a href="/wiki/Data_centers" class="mw-redirect" title="Data centers">data centers</a> around the world with several thousand servers in each. These data centers allowed Google to handle the ever-changing workload more efficiently.<sup id="cite_ref-Google_Inc_48-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Google_Inc-48">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2011, the number of monthly unique visitors to Google surpassed one billion for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> In May 2012, Google acquired <a href="/wiki/Motorola_Mobility" title="Motorola Mobility">Motorola Mobility</a> for $12.5&#160;billion, in its largest acquisition to date.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> This purchase was made in part to help Google gain Motorola's considerable patent portfolio on mobile phones and wireless technologies, to help protect Google in its ongoing patent disputes with other companies,<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> mainly <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> and to allow it to continue to freely offer Android.<sup id="cite_ref-cnet_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnet-86">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2012_onwards">2012 onwards</span></h3>
<p>In June 2013, Google acquired <a href="/wiki/Waze" title="Waze">Waze</a> for $966 million.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> While Waze would remain an independent entity, its social features, such as its crowdsourced location platform, were reportedly valuable integrations between Waze and <a href="/wiki/Google_Maps" title="Google Maps">Google Maps</a>, Google's own mapping service.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> Google announced the launch of a new company, called <a href="/wiki/Calico_(company)" title="Calico (company)">Calico</a>, on September 19, 2013, to be led by <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple Inc.</a> chairman <a href="/wiki/Arthur_D._Levinson" title="Arthur D. Levinson">Arthur Levinson</a>. In the official public statement, Page explained that the "health and well-being" company would focus on "the challenge of ageing and associated diseases".<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London,_6_Pancras_Square.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London%2C_6_Pancras_Square.jpg/170px-Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London%2C_6_Pancras_Square.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London%2C_6_Pancras_Square.jpg/255px-Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London%2C_6_Pancras_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London%2C_6_Pancras_Square.jpg/340px-Google-Deep_Mind_headquarters_in_London%2C_6_Pancras_Square.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2448" data-file-height="3264" /></a><figcaption>Entrance of building where Google and its subsidiary Deep Mind are located at 6 Pancras Square, London</figcaption></figure>
<p>On January 26, 2014, Google announced it had agreed to acquire <a href="/wiki/DeepMind_Technologies" class="mw-redirect" title="DeepMind Technologies">DeepMind Technologies</a>, a privately held artificial intelligence company from <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> Technology news website <i><a href="/wiki/Recode" title="Recode">Recode</a></i> reported that the company was purchased for $400 million, yet the source of the information was not disclosed. A Google spokesperson declined to comment on the price.<sup id="cite_ref-Helgren-_DeepMind_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Helgren-_DeepMind-91">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ribeiro-_DeepMind_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ribeiro-_DeepMind-92">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> The purchase of DeepMind aids in Google's recent growth in the artificial intelligence and robotics community.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> In 2015, DeepMind's <a href="/wiki/AlphaGo" title="AlphaGo">AlphaGo</a> became the first computer program to <a href="/wiki/AlphaGo_versus_Lee_Sedol" title="AlphaGo versus Lee Sedol">defeat a top human pro</a> at the game of Go.
</p><p>According to Interbrand's annual Best Global Brands report, Google has been the second most valuable brand in the world (behind <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple Inc.</a>) in 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> and 2016, with a valuation of $133 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 10, 2015, Google announced plans to reorganize its various interests as a <a href="/wiki/Conglomerate_(company)" title="Conglomerate (company)">conglomerate</a> named <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet Inc</a>. Google became Alphabet's largest subsidiary and the <a href="/wiki/Umbrella_company" title="Umbrella company">umbrella company</a> for Alphabet's Internet interests. Upon completion of the restructuring, <a href="/wiki/Sundar_Pichai" title="Sundar Pichai">Sundar Pichai</a> became <a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">CEO</a> of Google, replacing <a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a>, who became CEO of Alphabet.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_CEO_of_Google,_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister,_Shri_Narendra_Modi,_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17,_2015_(1).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/The_CEO_of_Google%2C_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17%2C_2015_%281%29.jpg/220px-The_CEO_of_Google%2C_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17%2C_2015_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/The_CEO_of_Google%2C_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17%2C_2015_%281%29.jpg/330px-The_CEO_of_Google%2C_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17%2C_2015_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/The_CEO_of_Google%2C_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17%2C_2015_%281%29.jpg/440px-The_CEO_of_Google%2C_Mr._Sundar_Pichai_calls_on_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_17%2C_2015_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2200" data-file-height="1524" /></a><figcaption>Current CEO, <a href="/wiki/Sundar_Pichai" title="Sundar Pichai">Sundar Pichai</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India" title="Prime Minister of India">Prime Minister of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>On August 8, 2017, Google fired employee James Damore after he distributed a memo throughout the company that argued bias and "<a href="/wiki/Google%27s_Ideological_Echo_Chamber" title="Google&#39;s Ideological Echo Chamber">Google's Ideological Echo Chamber</a>" clouded their thinking about diversity and inclusion, and that it is also biological factors, not discrimination alone, that cause the average woman to be less interested than men in technical positions.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> Google CEO Sundar Pichai accused Damore of violating company policy by "advancing harmful gender stereotypes in our workplace", and he was fired on the same day.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 2018 and 2019, <a href="/wiki/Google_worker_organization" title="Google worker organization">tensions between the company's leadership and its workers escalated</a> as staff protested company decisions on internal sexual harassment, <a href="/wiki/Dragonfly_(search_engine)" title="Dragonfly (search engine)">Dragonfly</a>, a censored Chinese search engine, and <a href="/wiki/Project_Maven" class="mw-redirect" title="Project Maven">Project Maven</a>, a military drone artificial intelligence, which had been seen as areas of revenue growth for the company.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Verge_busting_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Verge_busting-106">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> On October 25, 2018, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> published the <i>exposé</i>, "How Google Protected <a href="/wiki/Andy_Rubin" title="Andy Rubin">Andy Rubin</a>, the 'Father of Android'". The company subsequently announced that "48 employees have been fired over the last two years" for sexual misconduct.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> On November 1, 2018, more than 20,000 Google employees and contractors staged a global walk-out to protest the company's handling of sexual harassment complaints.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> CEO Sundar Pichai was reported to be in support of the protests.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> Later in 2019, some workers accused the company of retaliating against internal activists.<sup id="cite_ref-Verge_busting_106-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Verge_busting-106">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 19, 2019, Google announced that it would enter the video game market, launching a <a href="/wiki/Cloud_gaming" title="Cloud gaming">cloud gaming</a> platform called <a href="/wiki/Google_Stadia" title="Google Stadia">Google Stadia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unveils_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unveils-111">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 3, 2019, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">United States Department of Justice</a> reported that it would investigate Google for <a href="/wiki/Antitrust" class="mw-redirect" title="Antitrust">antitrust</a> violations.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> This led to the filing of an antitrust lawsuit in October 2020, on the grounds the company had abused a monopoly position in the <a href="/wiki/Web_search_engine" class="mw-redirect" title="Web search engine">search</a> and <a href="/wiki/Search_advertising" title="Search advertising">search advertising</a> markets.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2019, former <a href="/wiki/PayPal" title="PayPal">PayPal</a> <a href="/wiki/Chief_operating_officer" title="Chief operating officer">chief operating officer</a> Bill Ready became Google's new commerce chief. Ready's role will not be directly involved with <a href="/wiki/Google_Pay_(2018%E2%80%932022)" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Pay (2018–2022)">Google Pay</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2020, due to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, Google announced several cost-cutting measures. Such measures included slowing down hiring for the remainder of 2020, except for a small number of strategic areas, recalibrating the focus and pace of investments in areas like data centers and machines, and non-business essential marketing and travel.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> Most employees were also working from home due to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> and the success of it even led to Google announcing that they would be permanently converting some of their jobs to work from home <sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2020_Google_services_outages" class="mw-redirect" title="2020 Google services outages">2020 Google services outages</a> disrupted Google services: one in August that affected <a href="/wiki/Google_Drive" title="Google Drive">Google Drive</a> among others, another in November affecting <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>, and a third in December affecting the entire suite of Google applications. All three outages were resolved within hours.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, the <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Workers_Union" title="Alphabet Workers Union">Alphabet Workers Union</a> was founded, composed mostly of Google employees.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2021, the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Government" title="Australian Government">Australian Government</a> proposed legislation that would require Google and Facebook to pay media companies for the right to use their content. In response, Google threatened to close off access to its search engine in Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2021, Google reportedly paid $20 million for <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft" title="Ubisoft">Ubisoft</a> ports on <a href="/wiki/Google_Stadia" title="Google Stadia">Google Stadia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> Google spent "tens of millions of dollars" on getting major publishers such as <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft" title="Ubisoft">Ubisoft</a> and Take-Two to bring some of their biggest games to Stadia.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2021, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that Google ran a years-long program called "Project Bernanke" that used data from past advertising bids to gain an advantage over competing for ad services. This was revealed in documents concerning the antitrust lawsuit filed by ten US states against Google in December.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2021, the Australian government announced plans to curb Google's capability to sell targeted ads, claiming that the company has a monopoly on the market harming publishers, advertisers, and consumers.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2022, Google began accepting requests for the removal of phone numbers, physical addresses and email addresses from its search results. It had previously accepted requests for removing confidential data only, such as Social Security numbers, bank account and credit card numbers, personal signatures, and medical records. Even with the new policy, Google may remove information from only certain but not all search queries. It would not remove content that is "broadly useful", such as news articles, or already part of the public record.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2022, Google announced that the company had acquired California based, MicroLED display technology development and manufacturing Start-up Raxium. Raxium is set to join Google's Devices and Services team to aid in the development of micro-optics, monolithic integration, and system integration.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2023, following the success of <a href="/wiki/ChatGPT" title="ChatGPT">ChatGPT</a> and concerns that Google was falling behind in the AI race, Google's senior management issued a "code red" and a "directive that all of its most important products—those with more than a billion users—must incorporate generative AI within months".<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In early May 2023, Google announced its plans to build two additional data centers in Ohio. These centers, which will be built in Columbus and Lancaster, will power up the company's tools, including AI technology. The said data hub will add to the already operational center near Columbus, bringing Google's total investment in Ohio to over $2 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Products_and_services">Products and services</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Google_products" title="List of Google products">List of Google products</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Search_engine">Search engine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google Search</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Images" title="Google Images">Google Images</a></div>
<p>Google <a href="/wiki/Search_engine_indexing" title="Search engine indexing">indexes</a> billions of web pages to allow users to search for the information they desire through the use of keywords and <a href="/wiki/Operator_(computer_programming)" title="Operator (computer programming)">operators</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/ComScore" class="mw-redirect" title="ComScore">comScore</a> market research from November 2009, Google Search is the dominant search engine in the United States market, with a <a href="/wiki/Market_share" title="Market share">market share</a> of 65.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-comscore_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comscore-132">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup> In May 2017, Google enabled a new "Personal" tab in Google Search, letting users search for content in their Google accounts' various services, including email messages from Gmail and photos from <a href="/wiki/Google_Photos" title="Google Photos">Google Photos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google launched its <a href="/wiki/Google_News" title="Google News">Google News</a> service in 2002, an automated service which summarizes news articles from various websites.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> Google also hosts <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a>, a service which searches the text found in books in its database and shows limited previews or and the full book where allowed.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google expanded its search services to include <a href="/wiki/Google_Shopping" title="Google Shopping">shopping</a> (launched originally as Froogle in 2002),<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Finance" title="Google Finance">finance</a> (launched 2006),<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Flights" title="Google Flights">flights</a> (launched 2011).<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Advertising">Advertising</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ad-tech_London_2010_(2).JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Ad-tech_London_2010_%282%29.JPG/220px-Ad-tech_London_2010_%282%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Ad-tech_London_2010_%282%29.JPG/330px-Ad-tech_London_2010_%282%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Ad-tech_London_2010_%282%29.JPG/440px-Ad-tech_London_2010_%282%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448" /></a><figcaption>Google at ad-tech London, 2010</figcaption></figure>
<p>Google generates most of its revenues from advertising. This includes sales of apps, purchases made in-app, digital content products on Google and YouTube, Android and licensing and service fees, including fees received for Google Cloud offerings. Forty-six percent of this profit was from clicks (cost per clicks), amounting to US$109,652 million in 2017. This includes three principal methods, namely <a href="/wiki/AdMob" title="AdMob">AdMob</a>, <a href="/wiki/AdSense" class="mw-redirect" title="AdSense">AdSense</a> (such as AdSense for Content, <a href="/wiki/AdSense" class="mw-redirect" title="AdSense">AdSense</a> for Search, etc.) and <a href="/wiki/DoubleClick" title="DoubleClick">DoubleClick</a> AdExchange.<sup id="cite_ref-agm2017_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agm2017-140">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> In addition to its own algorithms for understanding search requests, Google uses technology from its acquisition of <a href="/wiki/DoubleClick" title="DoubleClick">DoubleClick</a>, to project user interest and target advertising to the search context and the user history.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> In 2007, Google launched "<a href="/wiki/AdSense_for_Mobile" class="mw-redirect" title="AdSense for Mobile">AdSense for Mobile</a>", taking advantage of the emerging mobile advertising market.<sup id="cite_ref-adsense_mobile_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-adsense_mobile-143">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Google_Analytics" title="Google Analytics">Google Analytics</a> allows website owners to track where and how people use their website, for example by examining click rates for all the links on a page.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> Google advertisements can be placed on third-party websites in a two-part program. <a href="/wiki/Google_Ads" title="Google Ads">Google Ads</a> allows advertisers to display their advertisements in the Google content network, through a cost-per-click scheme.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> The sister service, Google AdSense, allows website owners to display these advertisements on their website and earn money every time ads are clicked.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> One of the criticisms of this program is the possibility of <a href="/wiki/Click_fraud" title="Click fraud">click fraud</a>, which occurs when a person or automated script clicks on advertisements without being interested in the product, causing the advertiser to pay money to Google unduly. Industry reports in 2006 claimed that approximately 14 to 20&#160;percent of clicks were fraudulent or invalid.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Search_Console" title="Google Search Console">Google Search Console</a> (rebranded from Google Webmaster Tools in May 2015) allows <a href="/wiki/Webmasters" class="mw-redirect" title="Webmasters">webmasters</a> to check the sitemap, crawl rate, and for security issues of their websites, as well as optimize their website's visibility.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Artificial_intelligence">Artificial intelligence</span></h3>
<p>Google had previously utilized <a href="/wiki/Virtual_assistant" title="Virtual assistant">virtual assistants</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chatbot" title="Chatbot">chatbots</a>, such as Google Bard, prior to the announcement of <a href="/wiki/Gemini_(chatbot)" title="Gemini (chatbot)"><i>Gemini</i></a> in March 2024. None of them, however, had been seen as legitimate competitors to <a href="/wiki/ChatGPT" title="ChatGPT">ChatGPT</a>, unlike <i>Gemini.</i><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup>  An <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">artificial intelligence</a> training program for Google employees was also introduced in April 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Consumer_services">Consumer services</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Web-based_services">Web-based services</span></h4>
<p>Google offers <a href="/wiki/Gmail" title="Gmail">Gmail</a> for <a href="/wiki/Email" title="Email">email</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Calendar" title="Google Calendar">Google Calendar</a> for time-management and scheduling,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Maps" title="Google Maps">Google Maps</a> for mapping, navigation and <a href="/wiki/Satellite_imagery" title="Satellite imagery">satellite imagery</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Drive" title="Google Drive">Google Drive</a> for <a href="/wiki/File_hosting_service" class="mw-redirect" title="File hosting service">cloud storage</a> of files,<sup id="cite_ref-verge-drive-announced_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-drive-announced-153">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Docs" title="Google Docs">Google Docs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Sheets" title="Google Sheets">Sheets</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Slides" title="Google Slides">Slides</a> for productivity,<sup id="cite_ref-verge-drive-announced_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-drive-announced-153">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Photos" title="Google Photos">Google Photos</a> for photo storage and sharing,<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Keep" title="Google Keep">Google Keep</a> for <a href="/wiki/Note-taking" title="Note-taking">note-taking</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_Translate" title="Google Translate">Google Translate</a> for language translation,<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> for video viewing and sharing,<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Google_My_Business" class="mw-redirect" title="Google My Business">Google My Business</a> for managing public business information,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Duo" title="Google Duo">Duo</a> for social interaction.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> In March 2019, Google unveiled a <a href="/wiki/Cloud_gaming" title="Cloud gaming">cloud gaming</a> service named <a href="/wiki/Google_Stadia" title="Google Stadia">Stadia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unveils_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unveils-111">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> A job search product has also existed since before 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> Google for Jobs is an enhanced search feature that aggregates listings from <a href="/wiki/Job_board" class="mw-redirect" title="Job board">job boards</a> and career sites.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> Some Google services are not web-based. <a href="/wiki/Google_Earth" title="Google Earth">Google Earth</a>, launched in 2005, allows users to see high-definition satellite pictures from all over the world for free through a client software downloaded to their computers.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Software">Software</span></h4>
<p>Google develops the <a href="/wiki/Android_(operating_system)" title="Android (operating system)">Android</a> <a href="/wiki/Mobile_operating_system" title="Mobile operating system">mobile operating system</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> as well as its <a href="/wiki/Wear_OS" title="Wear OS">smartwatch</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Android_TV" title="Android TV">television</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Android_Auto" title="Android Auto">car</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Internet_of_things" title="Internet of things">Internet of things</a>-enabled <a href="/wiki/Android_Things" title="Android Things">smart devices</a> variations.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> It also develops the <a href="/wiki/Google_Chrome" title="Google Chrome">Google Chrome</a> web browser,<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/ChromeOS" title="ChromeOS">ChromeOS</a>, an operating system based on Chrome.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hardware">Hardware</span></h4>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Pixel_3_%E3%81%A8_Pixel_3_XL_%E3%82%92%E5%88%9D%E8%A7%A6%E3%80%82%E6%9C%AC%E4%BD%93%E3%82%92%E3%82%AE%E3%83%A5%E3%83%83%E3%81%A8%E6%8F%A1%E3%82%8B%E3%81%A8_Google_Assistant_%E3%81%8C%E7%AB%8B%E3%81%A1%E4%B8%8A%E3%81%8C%E3%82%8B%E3%81%AE%E3%81%8C%E3%81%8A%E3%82%82%E3%81%97%E3%82%8D%E3%81%84%E3%80%82_%E3%83%AF%E3%82%B7%E3%83%B3%E3%83%88%E3%83%B3DC_(44519013945).jpg"
