//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Pixel_3_%E3%81%A8_Pixel_3_XL_%E3%82%92%E5%88%9D%E8%A7%A6%E3%80%82%E6%9C%AC%E4%BD%93%E3%82%92%E3%82%AE%E3%83%A5%E3%83%83%E3%81%A8%E6%8F%A1%E3%82%8B%E3%81%A8_Google_Assistant_%E3%81%8C%E7%AB%8B%E3%81%A1%E4%B8%8A%E3%81%8C%E3%82%8B%E3%81%AE%E3%81%8C%E3%81%8A%E3%82%82%E3%81%97%E3%82%8D%E3%81%84%E3%80%82_%E3%83%AF%E3%82%B7%E3%83%B3%E3%83%88%E3%83%B3DC_%2844519013945%29.jpg/360px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1080" data-file-height="1146" /></a><figcaption>Google Pixel smartphones on display in a store</figcaption></figure>
<p>In January 2010, Google released <a href="/wiki/Nexus_One" title="Nexus One">Nexus One</a>, the first Android phone under its own brand.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> It spawned a number of phones and tablets under the "<a href="/wiki/Google_Nexus" title="Google Nexus">Nexus</a>" branding<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> until its eventual discontinuation in 2016, replaced by a new brand called <a href="/wiki/Google_Pixel" title="Google Pixel">Pixel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Pixel_inside_story_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pixel_inside_story-174">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Chromebook" title="Chromebook">Chromebook</a> was introduced, which runs on <a href="/wiki/ChromeOS" title="ChromeOS">ChromeOS</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2013, Google introduced the <a href="/wiki/Chromecast" title="Chromecast">Chromecast</a> dongle, which allows users to stream content from their smartphones to televisions.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2014, Google announced <a href="/wiki/Google_Cardboard" title="Google Cardboard">Google Cardboard</a>, a simple cardboard viewer that lets the user place their smartphone in a special front compartment to view <a href="/wiki/Virtual_reality" title="Virtual reality">virtual reality</a> (VR) media.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Other hardware products include:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Google_Nest_(smart_speakers)" title="Google Nest (smart speakers)">Nest</a>, a series of voice assistant smart speakers that can answer voice queries, play music, find information from apps (calendar, weather etc.), and control third-party smart home appliances (users can tell it to turn on the lights, for example). The Google Nest line includes the original <a href="/wiki/Google_Home" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Home">Google Home</a><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> (later succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Nest_Audio" class="mw-redirect" title="Nest Audio">Nest Audio</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Google_Home_Mini" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Home Mini">Google Home Mini</a> (later succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Nest_Mini" class="mw-redirect" title="Nest Mini">Nest Mini</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Google_Home_Max" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Home Max">Google Home Max</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Google_Home_Hub" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Home Hub">Google Home Hub</a> (later rebranded as the Nest Hub), and the <a href="/wiki/Nest_Hub_Max" class="mw-redirect" title="Nest Hub Max">Nest Hub Max</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Google_Nest_Wifi" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Nest Wifi">Nest Wifi</a> (originally Google Wifi), a connected set of <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a> routers to simplify and extend coverage of home Wi-Fi.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Enterprise_services">Enterprise services<span class="anchor" id="Enterprise_products"></span></span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Google_Workspace" title="Google Workspace">Google Workspace</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Cloud_Platform" title="Google Cloud Platform">Google Cloud Platform</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Google_Workspace" title="Google Workspace">Google Workspace</a> (formerly G Suite until October 2020<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup>) is a monthly subscription offering for organizations and businesses to get access to a collection of Google's services, including <a href="/wiki/Gmail" title="Gmail">Gmail</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Drive" title="Google Drive">Google Drive</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Docs" title="Google Docs">Google Docs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Sheets" title="Google Sheets">Google Sheets</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google_Slides" title="Google Slides">Google Slides</a>, with additional administrative tools, unique domain names, and 24/7 support.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 24, 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> Google launched <a href="/wiki/Google_for_Entrepreneurs" class="mw-redirect" title="Google for Entrepreneurs">Google for Entrepreneurs</a>, a largely not-for-profit <a href="/wiki/Business_incubator" title="Business incubator">business incubator</a> providing startups with <a href="/wiki/Coworking" title="Coworking">co-working spaces</a> known as Campuses, with assistance to startup founders that may include workshops, conferences, and mentorships.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> Presently, there are seven Campus locations: <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>.
</p><p>On March 15, 2016, Google announced the introduction of Google Analytics 360 Suite, "a set of integrated data and marketing analytics products, designed specifically for the needs of enterprise-class marketers" which can be integrated with <a href="/wiki/BigQuery" title="BigQuery">BigQuery</a> on the Google Cloud Platform. Among other things, the suite is designed to help "enterprise class marketers" "see the complete <a href="/wiki/Customer_journey" class="mw-redirect" title="Customer journey">customer journey</a>", generate "useful insights", and "deliver engaging experiences to the right people".<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> Jack Marshall of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> wrote that the suite competes with existing marketing cloud offerings by companies including <a href="/wiki/Adobe_Systems" class="mw-redirect" title="Adobe Systems">Adobe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oracle_Corporation" title="Oracle Corporation">Oracle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salesforce.com" class="mw-redirect" title="Salesforce.com">Salesforce</a>, and <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internet_services">Internet services</span></h3>
<p>In February 2010, Google announced the <a href="/wiki/Google_Fiber" title="Google Fiber">Google Fiber</a> project, with experimental plans to build an ultra-high-speed broadband network for 50,000 to 500,000 customers in one or more American cities.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> Following Google's corporate restructure to make Alphabet Inc. its parent company, <a href="/wiki/Google_Fiber" title="Google Fiber">Google Fiber</a> was moved to Alphabet's Access division.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2015, Google announced <a href="/wiki/Project_Fi" class="mw-redirect" title="Project Fi">Project Fi</a>, a mobile virtual network operator, that combines Wi-Fi and cellular networks from different telecommunication providers in an effort to enable seamless connectivity and fast Internet signal.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Financial_services">Financial services</span></h3>
<p>In August 2023, Google became the first major tech company to join the <a href="/wiki/OpenWallet_Foundation" class="mw-redirect" title="OpenWallet Foundation">OpenWallet Foundation</a>, launched earlier in the year, whose goal was creating open-source software for interoperable digital wallets.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_affairs">Corporate affairs</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Stock_price_performance_and_quarterly_earnings">Stock price performance and quarterly earnings</span></h3>
<p>Google's <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">initial public offering</a> (IPO) took place on August 19, 2004. At IPO, the company offered 19,605,052 shares at a price of $85 per share.<sup id="cite_ref-IPO_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPO-67">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-68">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> The sale of $1.67 billion gave Google a <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of more than $23 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-washpost_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-washpost-71">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> The stock performed well after the IPO, with shares hitting $350 for the first time on October 31, 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> primarily because of strong sales and earnings in the <a href="/wiki/Online_advertising" title="Online advertising">online advertising</a> market.<sup id="cite_ref-bowlingforgoogle_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bowlingforgoogle-195">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> The surge in stock price was fueled mainly by individual investors, as opposed to large institutional investors and <a href="/wiki/Mutual_fund" title="Mutual fund">mutual funds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bowlingforgoogle_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bowlingforgoogle-195">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> GOOG shares split into GOOG <a href="/wiki/Class_C_share" class="mw-redirect" title="Class C share">class C shares</a> and GOOGL <a href="/wiki/Class_A_share" title="Class A share">class A shares</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> The company is listed on the <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" class="mw-redirect" title="NASDAQ">NASDAQ</a> stock exchange under the <a href="/wiki/Ticker_symbol" title="Ticker symbol">ticker symbols</a> GOOGL and GOOG, and on the <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Stock_Exchange" title="Frankfurt Stock Exchange">Frankfurt Stock Exchange</a> under the ticker symbol GGQ1. These ticker symbols now refer to Alphabet Inc., Google's holding company, since the fourth quarter of 2015.<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the third quarter of 2005, Google reported a 700% increase in profit, largely due to large companies shifting their advertising strategies from newspapers, magazines, and television to the Internet.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>For the 2006 fiscal year, the company reported $10.492 billion in total advertising revenues and only $112 million in licensing and other revenues.<sup id="cite_ref-10-K_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10-K-201">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> In 2011, 96% of Google's revenue was derived from its advertising programs.<sup id="cite_ref-Google-Inc-Jan-2012-10-K_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Google-Inc-Jan-2012-10-K-202">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google generated $50 billion in annual revenue for the first time in 2012, generating $38 billion the previous year. In January 2013, then-CEO Larry Page commented, "We ended 2012 with a strong quarter ... Revenues were up 36% year-on-year, and 8% quarter-on-quarter. And we hit $50 billion in revenues for the first time last year – not a bad achievement in just a decade and a half."<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google's consolidated revenue for the third quarter of 2013 was reported in mid-October 2013 as $14.89 billion, a 12 percent increase compared to the previous quarter.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> Google's Internet business was responsible for $10.8 billion of this total, with an increase in the number of users' clicks on advertisements.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> By January 2014, Google's market capitalization had grown to $397 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-Marketwatch_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marketwatch-206">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tax_avoidance_strategies">Tax avoidance strategies</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Corporation_tax_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland#Multinational_tax_schemes" title="Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland">Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland §&#160;Multinational tax schemes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Google_tax" title="Google tax">Google tax</a></div>
<p>Google uses various <a href="/wiki/Tax_avoidance" title="Tax avoidance">tax avoidance</a> strategies. On the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_technology_companies_by_revenue" title="List of largest technology companies by revenue">list of largest technology companies by revenue</a>, it pays the lowest taxes to the countries of origin of its revenues. Google between 2007 and 2010 saved $3.1 billion in taxes by shuttling non-U.S. profits through <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> and then to <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>. Such techniques lower its non-U.S. tax rate to 2.3 per cent, while normally the corporate tax rate in, for instance, the UK is 28 per cent.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> This reportedly sparked a French investigation into Google's <a href="/wiki/Transfer_pricing" title="Transfer pricing">transfer pricing</a> practices in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2020, Google said it had overhauled its controversial global tax structure and consolidated all of its intellectual property holdings back to the US.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google Vice-president <a href="/wiki/Matt_Brittin" title="Matt Brittin">Matt Brittin</a> testified to the <a href="/wiki/Public_Accounts_Committee_(United_Kingdom)" title="Public Accounts Committee (United Kingdom)">Public Accounts Committee</a> of the <a href="/wiki/UK_House_of_Commons" class="mw-redirect" title="UK House of Commons">UK House of Commons</a> that his UK sales team made no sales and hence owed no sales taxes to the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> In January 2016, Google reached a settlement with the UK to pay £130m in back taxes plus higher taxes in future.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> In 2017, Google channeled $22.7 billion from the Netherlands to Bermuda to reduce its tax bill.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, Google ranked 5th in <a href="/wiki/Lobbying_in_the_United_States" title="Lobbying in the United States">lobbying</a> spending, up from 213th in 2003. In 2012, the company ranked 2nd in campaign donations of technology and Internet sections.<sup id="cite_ref-lobby1_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lobby1-213">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_identity">Corporate identity</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Google#Name" title="History of Google">History of Google §&#160;Name</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_(verb)" title="Google (verb)">Google (verb)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_logo" title="Google logo">Google logo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Doodle" title="Google Doodle">Google Doodle</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Google_April_Fools%27_Day_jokes" title="List of Google April Fools&#39; Day jokes">List of Google April Fools' Day jokes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Google_Easter_eggs" title="List of Google Easter eggs">List of Google Easter eggs</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google_logo_(2013-2015).svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Google_logo_%282013-2015%29.svg/200px-Google_logo_%282013-2015%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="69" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Google_logo_%282013-2015%29.svg/300px-Google_logo_%282013-2015%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Google_logo_%282013-2015%29.svg/400px-Google_logo_%282013-2015%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="258" /></a><figcaption>Google's logo from 2013 to 2015</figcaption></figure>
<p>The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "<a href="/wiki/Googol" title="Googol">googol</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hanley_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hanley-215">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> which refers to the number represented by a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros. Page and Brin write in their original paper on <a href="/wiki/PageRank" title="PageRank">PageRank</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-originalpaper_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-originalpaper-34">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> "We chose our system name, Google, because it is a common spelling of googol, or 10<sup>100</sup>[,] and fits well with our goal of building very large-scale search engines." Having found its way increasingly into everyday language, the verb "google" was added to the <i><a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster_Collegiate_Dictionary" class="mw-redirect" title="Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary">Merriam Webster Collegiate Dictionary</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> in 2006, meaning "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet."<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> Google's <a href="/wiki/Mission_statement" title="Mission statement">mission statement</a>, from the outset, was "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful",<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> and its unofficial slogan is "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_be_evil" title="Don&#39;t be evil">Don't be evil</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> In October 2015, a related motto was adopted in the Alphabet corporate code of conduct by the phrase: "Do the right thing".<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> The original motto was retained in the code of conduct of Google, now a subsidiary of Alphabet.
</p><p>The original Google logo was designed by Sergey Brin.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> Since 1998,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> Google has been designing special, temporary alternate logos to place on their homepage intended to celebrate holidays, events, achievements and people. The first <a href="/wiki/Google_Doodle" title="Google Doodle">Google Doodle</a> was in honor of the <a href="/wiki/Burning_Man" title="Burning Man">Burning Man Festival</a> of 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> The doodle was designed by <a href="/wiki/Larry_Page" title="Larry Page">Larry Page</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Brin" title="Sergey Brin">Sergey Brin</a> to notify users of their absence in case the servers crashed. Subsequent Google Doodles were designed by an outside contractor, until Larry and Sergey asked then-<a href="/wiki/Intern" class="mw-redirect" title="Intern">intern</a> <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Hwang" title="Dennis Hwang">Dennis Hwang</a> to design a logo for <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">Bastille Day</a> in 2000. From that point onward, Doodles have been organized and created by a team of employees termed "Doodlers".<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google has a tradition of creating <a href="/wiki/April_Fools%27_Day" title="April Fools&#39; Day">April Fools' Day</a> jokes. Its first on April 1, 2000, was <a href="/wiki/Google%27s_hoaxes#2000" class="mw-redirect" title="Google&#39;s hoaxes">Google MentalPlex</a> which allegedly featured the use of mental power to search the web.<sup id="cite_ref-mentalplex_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mentalplex-225">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> In 2007, Google announced a free Internet service called <a href="/wiki/TiSP" class="mw-redirect" title="TiSP">TiSP</a>, or Toilet Internet Service Provider, where one obtained a connection by flushing one end of a <a href="/wiki/Optical_fiber" title="Optical fiber">fiber-optic</a> cable down their toilet.<sup id="cite_ref-TiSP_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TiSP-226">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google's services contain <a href="/wiki/Easter_egg_(media)" title="Easter egg (media)">easter eggs</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Chef" title="Swedish Chef">Swedish Chef</a>'s "Bork bork bork," <a href="/wiki/Pig_Latin" title="Pig Latin">Pig Latin</a>, "Hacker" or <a href="/wiki/Leet" title="Leet">leetspeak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elmer_Fudd" title="Elmer Fudd">Elmer Fudd</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Talk_Like_a_Pirate_Day" title="International Talk Like a Pirate Day">Pirate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Klingon_language" title="Klingon language">Klingon</a> as language selections for its search engine.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> When searching for the word "<a href="/wiki/Anagram" title="Anagram">anagram</a>," meaning a rearrangement of letters from one word to form other valid words, Google's suggestion feature displays "Did you mean: nag a ram?"<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> Since 2019, Google runs free online courses to help engineers learn how to plan and author <a href="/wiki/Technical_documentation" title="Technical documentation">technical documentation</a> better.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Workplace_culture">Workplace culture<span class="anchor" id="Innovation_Time_Off"></span><span class="anchor" id="Employees"></span></span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png/220px-Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png/330px-Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png/440px-Pride_in_London_2016_-_Google_participating_in_the_parade.png 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>Google employees marching in the <a href="/wiki/Pride_in_London" title="Pride in London">Pride in London</a> parade in 2016</figcaption></figure>
<p>On <i><a href="/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)" title="Fortune (magazine)">Fortune</a></i> magazine's list of the best companies to work for, Google ranked first in 2007, 2008 and 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-best_company_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-best_company-230">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> and fourth in 2009 and 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> Google was also nominated in 2010 to be the world's most attractive employer to graduating students in the Universum Communications talent attraction index.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> Google's corporate philosophy includes principles such as "you can make money without doing evil," "you can be serious without a suit," and "work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun."<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of September&#160;30,&#32;2020,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> Alphabet Inc. had 132,121 employees,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> of which more than 100,000 worked for Google.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-9">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Google's 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> diversity report states that 32 percent of its workforce are women and 68 percent are men, with the ethnicity of its workforce being predominantly white (51.7%) and Asian (41.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> Within tech roles, 23.6 percent were women; and 26.7 percent of leadership roles were held by women.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> In addition to its 100,000+ full-time employees, Google used about 121,000 temporary workers and contractors, as of March&#160;2019.<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:0_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-9">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google's employees are hired based on a hierarchical system. Employees are split into six hierarchies based on experience and can range "from entry-level data center workers at level one to managers and experienced engineers at level six."<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> As a motivation technique, Google uses a policy known as <a href="/wiki/Innovation_Time_Off" class="mw-redirect" title="Innovation Time Off">Innovation Time Off</a>, where Google engineers are encouraged to spend 20% of their work time on projects that interest them. Some of Google's services, such as Gmail, <a href="/wiki/Google_News" title="Google News">Google News</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orkut" title="Orkut">Orkut</a>, and <a href="/wiki/AdSense" class="mw-redirect" title="AdSense">AdSense</a>, originated from these independent endeavors.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> In a talk at Stanford University, <a href="/wiki/Marissa_Mayer" title="Marissa Mayer">Marissa Mayer</a>, Google's vice-president of Search Products and User Experience until July 2012, showed that half of all new product launches in the second half of 2005 had originated from the Innovation Time Off.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, articles in <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, no evil philosophy.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> In an effort to maintain the company's unique culture, Google designated a Chief Culture Officer whose purpose was to develop and maintain the culture and work on ways to keep true to the core values that the company was founded on.<sup id="cite_ref-CCO_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCO-247">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> Google has also faced allegations of <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ageism" title="Ageism">ageism</a> from former employees.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> In 2013, a <a href="/wiki/High-Tech_Employee_Antitrust_Litigation" title="High-Tech Employee Antitrust Litigation">class action against</a> several <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a> companies, including Google, was filed for alleged "no cold call" agreements which restrained the recruitment of high-tech employees.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> In a lawsuit filed January 8, 2018, multiple employees and job applicants alleged Google discriminated against a class defined by their "conservative political views[,] male gender[,] and/or [...] Caucasian or Asian race".<sup id="cite_ref-:4_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-251">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 25, 2020, the formation of an international workers union of Google employees, Alpha Global, was announced.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> The coalition is made up of "13 different unions representing workers in 10 countries, including the United States, [the] United Kingdom, and Switzerland."<sup id="cite_ref-:5_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-253">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> The group is affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/UNI_Global_Union" title="UNI Global Union">UNI Global Union</a>, which represents nearly 20 million international workers from various unions and federations. The formation of the union is in response to persistent allegations of mistreatment of Google employees and a toxic workplace culture.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_253-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-253">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:4_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-251">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> Google had previously been accused of surveilling and firing employees who were suspected of organizing a workers union.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> In 2021, court documents revealed that between 2018 and 2020, Google ran an anti-union campaign called Project Vivian to "convince them (employees) that unions suck".<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Office_locations">Office locations <span class="anchor" id="Office_locations_and_headquarters"></span></span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Googleplex" title="Googleplex">Googleplex</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg/220px-111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg/330px-111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg/440px-111_Eighth_Avenue.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3911" data-file-height="2653" /></a><figcaption>Google's New York City office building houses its largest advertising sales team.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="98" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Google_at_111_Richmond_Street_West_in_Toronto_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3156" data-file-height="1406" /></a><figcaption>Google's <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a> office</figcaption></figure>
<p>Google's headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Mountain_View,_California" title="Mountain View, California">Mountain View</a>, California is referred to as "the <a href="/wiki/Googleplex" title="Googleplex">Googleplex</a>", a play on words on the number <a href="/wiki/Googolplex" title="Googolplex">googolplex</a> and the headquarters itself being a <i>complex</i> of buildings. Internationally, Google has over 78 offices in more than 50 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, Google moved into about 300,000 square feet (27,900&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) of office space at <a href="/wiki/111_Eighth_Avenue" title="111 Eighth Avenue">111 Eighth Avenue</a> in <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>. The office was designed and built specially for Google, and houses its largest advertising sales team.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> In 2010, Google bought the building housing the headquarter, in a deal that valued the property at around $1.9 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> In March 2018, Google's parent company Alphabet bought the nearby <a href="/wiki/Chelsea_Market" title="Chelsea Market">Chelsea Market</a> building for $2.4 billion. The sale is touted as one of the most expensive real estate transactions for a single building in the history of New York.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> In November 2018, Google announced its plan to expand its New York City office to a capacity of 12,000 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> The same December, it was announced that a $1 billion, 1,700,000-square-foot (160,000&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) headquarters for Google would be built in Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Square" title="Hudson Square">Hudson Square</a> neighborhood.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> Called Google Hudson Square, the new campus is projected to more than double the number of Google employees working in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By late 2006, Google established a new headquarters for its AdWords division in <a href="/wiki/Ann_Arbor,_Michigan" title="Ann Arbor, Michigan">Ann Arbor, Michigan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> In November 2006, Google opened offices on <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon" class="mw-redirect" title="Carnegie Mellon">Carnegie Mellon</a>'s campus in <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, focusing on shopping-related advertisement coding and <a href="/wiki/Smartphone_applications" class="mw-redirect" title="Smartphone applications">smartphone applications</a> and programs.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> Other office locations in the U.S. include <a href="/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlanta, Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a>; <a href="/wiki/Austin,_Texas" title="Austin, Texas">Austin, Texas</a>; <a href="/wiki/Boulder,_Colorado" title="Boulder, Colorado">Boulder, Colorado</a>; <a href="/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts" title="Cambridge, Massachusetts">Cambridge, Massachusetts</a>; <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>, <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>; <a href="/wiki/Seattle,_Washington" class="mw-redirect" title="Seattle, Washington">Seattle, Washington</a>; <a href="/wiki/Kirkland,_Washington" title="Kirkland, Washington">Kirkland, Washington</a>; <a href="/wiki/Birmingham,_Michigan" title="Birmingham, Michigan">Birmingham, Michigan</a>; <a href="/wiki/Reston,_Virginia" title="Reston, Virginia">Reston, Virginia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Madison,_Wisconsin" title="Madison, Wisconsin">Madison, Wisconsin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg/220px-Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg/330px-Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg/440px-Google_Headquarters_in_Ireland_Building_Sign.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2424" data-file-height="1820" /></a><figcaption>Google's Dublin Ireland office, headquarters of Google Ads for Europe</figcaption></figure>
<p>It also has product research and development operations in cities around the world, namely <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a> (birthplace location of <a href="/wiki/Google_Maps" title="Google Maps">Google Maps</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> (part of Android development).<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> In November 2013, Google announced plans for a new <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> headquarter, a 1 million square foot office able to accommodate 4,500 employees. Recognized as one of the biggest ever commercial property acquisitions at the time of the deal's announcement in January,<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> Google submitted plans for the new headquarter to the <a href="/wiki/Camden_London_Borough_Council" title="Camden London Borough Council">Camden Council</a> in June 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> In May 2015, Google announced its intention to create its own campus in <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad" title="Hyderabad">Hyderabad</a>, India. The new campus, reported to be the company's largest outside the United States, will accommodate 13,000 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google's Global Offices sum a total of 85 Locations worldwide,<sup id="cite_ref-Google_world_office_locations_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Google_world_office_locations-281">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> with 32 offices in North America, 3 of them in <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> and 29 in <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> Territory, <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a> being the state with the most Google's offices with 9 in total including the <a href="/wiki/Googleplex" title="Googleplex">Googleplex</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> Region Google counts with 6 offices, in Europe 24 (3 of them in <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">UK</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia-Pacific">Asia Pacific</a> region counts with 18 offices principally 4 in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and 3 in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> region counts 5 offices.
</p>

</td></tr>
<tr>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Google_data_centers" title="Google data centers">Google data centers</a></div>
<p>Google has data centers in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> There is no official data on the number of <a href="/wiki/Server_(computing)" title="Server (computing)">servers</a> in Google data centers; however, research and advisory firm <a href="/wiki/Gartner" title="Gartner">Gartner</a> estimated in a July 2016 report that Google at the time had 2.5 million servers.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> Traditionally, Google relied on <a href="/wiki/Parallel_computing" title="Parallel computing">parallel computing</a> on commodity hardware like mainstream <a href="/wiki/X86" title="X86">x86</a> computers (similar to home PCs) to keep costs per query low.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CNET2009_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNET2009-286">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> In 2005, it started developing its own designs, which were only revealed in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-CNET2009_286-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNET2009-286">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google has built its own private <a href="/wiki/Submarine_communications_cable" title="Submarine communications cable">submarine communications cables</a>. The first cable, named Curie, connects <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a> with <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and was completed on November 15, 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> The second fully Google-owned undersea cable, named Dunant, connects the United States with France and is planned to begin operation in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> Google's third subsea cable, Equiano, will connect <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> with <a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> The company's fourth cable, named Grace Hopper, connects landing points in <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">New York, US</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bude" title="Bude">Bude</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">UK</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bilbao" title="Bilbao">Bilbao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, and is expected to become operational in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<p>In October 2006, the company announced plans to install thousands of <a href="/wiki/Solar_panel" title="Solar panel">solar panels</a> to provide up to 1.6 <a href="/wiki/MegaWatt" class="mw-redirect" title="MegaWatt">Megawatt</a> of electricity, enough to satisfy approximately 30% of the campus' energy needs.<sup id="cite_ref-solar_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solar-292">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> The system is the largest <a href="/wiki/Rooftop_photovoltaic_power_station" class="mw-redirect" title="Rooftop photovoltaic power station">rooftop photovoltaic power station</a> constructed on a U.S. corporate campus and one of the largest on any corporate site in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-solar_292-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solar-292">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> Since 2007,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> Google has aimed for <a href="/wiki/Carbon_neutrality" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon neutrality">carbon neutrality</a> in regard to its operations.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Google disclosed in September 2011 that it "continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes", almost 260 million watts or about a quarter of the output of a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a>. Total carbon emissions for 2010 were just under 1.5 million metric tons, mostly due to fossil fuels that provide electricity for the data centers. Google said that 25 percent of its energy was supplied by renewable fuels in 2010. An average search uses only 0.3 watt-hours of electricity, so all global searches are only 12.5 million watts or 5% of the total electricity consumption by Google.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Google_Energy" title="Google Energy">Google Energy</a> made its first investment in a <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> project, putting $38.8&#160;million into two <a href="/wiki/Wind_farm" title="Wind farm">wind farms</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_Dakota" title="North Dakota">North Dakota</a>. The company announced the two locations will generate 169.5&#160;megawatts of power, enough to supply 55,000 homes.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup> In February 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Energy_Regulatory_Commission" title="Federal Energy Regulatory Commission">Federal Energy Regulatory Commission</a> granted Google an authorization to buy and sell energy at market rates.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> The corporation exercised this authorization in September 2013 when it announced it would purchase all the electricity produced by the not-yet-built 240-megawatt Happy Hereford wind farm.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2010, Google signed an agreement with an <a href="/wiki/Iowa" title="Iowa">Iowa</a> wind farm to buy 114 megawatts of power for 20 years.<sup id="cite_ref-wind_energy_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wind_energy-299">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2016, Google announced that—starting in 2017—it would purchase enough renewable energy to match 100% of the energy usage of its data centers and offices. The commitment will make Google "the world's largest corporate buyer of renewable power, with commitments reaching 2.6 gigawatts (2,600 megawatts) of wind and solar energy".<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2017, Google bought 536 megawatts of wind power. The purchase made the firm reach <a href="/wiki/100%25_renewable_energy" title="100% renewable energy">100% renewable energy</a>. The wind energy comes from two power plants in <a href="/wiki/South_Dakota" title="South Dakota">South Dakota</a>, one in Iowa and one in <a href="/wiki/Oklahoma" title="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> In September 2019, Google's chief executive announced plans for a $2 billion wind and solar investment, the biggest renewable energy deal in corporate history. This will grow their green energy profile by 40%, giving them an extra 1.6 gigawatt of clean energy, the company said.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2020, Google announced it had retroactively offset all of its carbon emissions since the company's foundation in 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> It also stated that it is committed to operating its data centers and offices using only carbon-free energy by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup> In October 2020, the company pledged to make the packaging for its hardware products 100% plastic-free and 100% recyclable by 2025. It also said that all its final assembly manufacturing sites will achieve a <a href="/wiki/UL_(safety_organization)" title="UL (safety organization)">UL</a> 2799 <a href="/wiki/Zero_waste#Corporate_initiatives" title="Zero waste">Zero Waste to Landfill</a> certification by 2022 by ensuring that the vast majority of waste from the manufacturing process is recycled instead of ending up in a landfill.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate_change_denial_and_misinformation">Climate change denial and misinformation</span></h4>
<p>Google donates to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_denial" title="Climate change denial">climate change denial</a> political groups including the <a href="/wiki/State_Policy_Network" title="State Policy Network">State Policy Network</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Competitive_Enterprise_Institute" title="Competitive Enterprise Institute">Competitive Enterprise Institute</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> The company also actively funds and profits from climate <a href="/wiki/Disinformation" title="Disinformation">disinformation</a> by monetizing ad spaces on most of the largest climate disinformation sites.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup> Google continued to monetize and profit from sites propagating climate disinformation even after the company updated their policy to prohibit placing their ads on similar sites.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy">Philanthropy</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Google.org" title="Google.org">Google.org</a></div>
<p>In 2004, Google formed the not-for-profit philanthropic Google.org, with a start-up fund of $1&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-philanthropy_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-philanthropy-312">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> The mission of the organization is to create <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_education" title="Climate change education">awareness about climate change</a>, global public health, and global poverty. One of its first projects was to develop a viable <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_hybrid" title="Plug-in hybrid">plug-in hybrid</a> <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle" title="Electric vehicle">electric vehicle</a> that can attain 100 miles per gallon. Google hired <a href="/wiki/Larry_Brilliant" title="Larry Brilliant">Larry Brilliant</a> as the program's executive director in 2004<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> and Megan Smith has since<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Google&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> replaced him as director.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2007, in partnership with the <a href="/wiki/Mathematical_Sciences_Research_Institute" class="mw-redirect" title="Mathematical Sciences Research Institute">Mathematical Sciences Research Institute</a> (MSRI), Google hosted the first <a href="/wiki/Julia_Robinson_Mathematics_Festival" title="Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival">Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival</a> at its headquarters in Mountain View.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup> In 2011, Google donated 1&#160;million euros to <a href="/wiki/International_Mathematical_Olympiad" title="International Mathematical Olympiad">International Mathematical Olympiad</a> to support the next five annual International Mathematical Olympiads (2011–2015).<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> In July 2012, Google launched a "<a href="/wiki/Legalize_Love" class="mw-redirect" title="Legalize Love">Legalize Love</a>" campaign in support of <a href="/wiki/Gay_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Gay rights">gay rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2008, Google announced its "project 10<sup>100</sup>", which accepted ideas for how to help the community and then allowed Google users to vote on their favorites.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> After two years of no update, during which many wondered what had happened to the program,<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> Google revealed the winners of the project, giving a total of ten million dollars to various ideas ranging from non-profit organizations that promote education to a website that intends to make all legal documents public and online.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Responding to the humanitarian crisis after the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, Google announced a $15 million donation to support Ukrainian citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> The company also decided to transform its office in Warsaw into a help center for refugees.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in February 2022, Google announced a $100 million fund to expand skills training and job placement for low-income Americans, in conjunction with non-profits <a href="/wiki/Year_Up" title="Year Up">Year Up</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Finance_(consultancy)" title="Social Finance (consultancy)">Social Finance</a>, and Merit America.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism_and_controversies">Criticism and controversies</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Google" title="Criticism of Google">Criticism of Google</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_by_Google" title="Censorship by Google">Censorship by Google</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Privacy_concerns_regarding_Google" class="mw-redirect" title="Privacy concerns regarding Google">Privacy concerns regarding Google</a></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Summarize plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style" href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Google" title="Criticism of Google">Criticism of Google</a>.</b><span class="hide-when-compact"> See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary
